Improved Management Effectiveness of the Chobe- Kwando Linyanti Matrix of Protected areas
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Provide technical support for sustainable land management practices and reduce human wildlife conflict

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

The establishment and implementation of the collaborative governance framework will improve; 1. Successful management of environment at landscape level 2. . Security for wildlife movements across units including access to critical dispersal areas and water sources 3. Compatibility of land/natural resource uses with overall biodiversity management goals 4. Reduction in land-use conflicts and Human Wildlife Conflict An increase in the management effectiveness of the Chobe-Kwando Linyanti Matrix of protected areas will result in; 1. Increasing PA budgets 2. Technical support to develop economic case for increased budgets to Chobe Protected Area complex (e.g. revenue retention, private sector financing, Payment for Ecosystem Services schemes and other innovative resource mobilization methods under a co-management framework) 3. Business plan for Chobe-Kwando Linyanti matrix developed and implemented to generate additional financing 4. Implementing accountable and performance-based management systems 5. Linking human resources to PA management outcomes 6. Developing staff capacity 7. Developing a guide to long-term PA staffing plan and HR development 8. Increasing learning and peer exchanges 9. Economies of scale in the tourism sector 10. Strengthening management effectiveness in buffer zones and multiple use area

comment.narrative:
Base line 1. There is no collaborative governance framework in place for protected areas
2. The management effectiveness and financial sustainability in Core Protected Areas is not adequate to address the existing and emerging threats to biodiversity

1. Develop an integrated land use plan for Chobe employing the stakeholder participatory methodologies 2.Identification of key 14 tourism sites( 8 linked with communities and 6 in the Forest reserves 3.Human resource training/ capacity development 4.Fire Management Strategy developed and implemented by all stakeholders

1. Integrated Land Use consultants already engaged to Develop a Chobe District Integrated Land Use Plan. -Communities Consultative meetings conducted to solicit input from community members and the Tribal Leadership -Government Officials consultative meetings conducted by the consultants as well. -Inception Report shared with all Stakeholders and presented to the Reference Group -Consultants to present revised Inception Draft report on 29th Nov'16. 2. Target moved to 2017 AWP 3. Two DWNP staff supported to train on UNDP/GEF -Stap development of methods to meaasure socio-economic impact of Protected Areas. The project has continue to support the Project Sponsored Students from Pandamatenga on their tourism trainings currently on-going. The students are currently on internship and are due to complete their studies on March 2017. 4. Activity Completed/achieved. Only left activity is to support the CBFMCs with Protective clothing scheduled for 2017 in the AWP.

description.narrative: To strengthen management effectiveness of the ChobeKwandoLinyanti Matrix of PAs to respond to existing and emerging threats

Community benefits and participation
HH income especially in poor areas

comment.narrative:
P6m to committee P750000 to villages
0 HH benefit
15 increase in HH income in CBNRM areas

Hunting Ban in Botswana has affected the income generation of the Community Based Organizations for CBNRM but the project has engaged in assisting communities to build sustainable rural livelihoods that will reduce poverty and dependency on natural resources Those activities include
introduction of conservation farming
upgrading of the Chobe Enclave Conservation Trusts milling and brick molding projects so that they create more jobs for the communities
supporting the Chobe Fresh and Dry Fish Association

description.narrative:
PA budgets secure
PA management indicators including status of LE habitats and wildlife populations

comment.narrative:
P8m
Nil

PA budgets of P15m cover operational costs for 14000km2 and used effectively according to activitybased budgets and stakeholder review
14776km2 PA CNP10600 km FRs 4176 km2 and 11149km2 buffer zones 8998km2 CHAs 2151 km2 occupied State Lands have measurable resource protection habitat and wildlife monitoring and PA management indicators detailed below are monitored and improving ie habitats and wildlife poaching fire problem animals tourism stakeholder and tourist satisfaction
Activities planned for Year 2

description.narrative: Reduced land use and wildlife conflicts

comment.narrative: 510 lions HWC
23 lions HWC

Awareness creation on HWC through community meetings traditional kgotla set up system held in seven 7 villages in the project area The discussions on HWC were centered on the establishment and support of human wildlife coexistence programmes like promoting sustainable rural livelihoods options that are suitable for HWC prone area like Chobe District

description.narrative: Tourism expansion and diversification in FR CBNRM areas and CNP

comment.narrative: 1200 beds

PAC in CBNRM areas reduced to 30 of current levels through benefit sharing and management plans
Tourism activities diversified with
250300 beds in new areas

The expansion strategies are delayed by the development of the Integrated Land Use Plan of the project area ie the development of the management plans for the CBNRM areas and the development of the SEA and management plans for the Forest Reserves All these are expected to be completed by the first quarter in 2016 them the tourism initiatives could start

description.narrative: Wildlife corridors

comment.narrative: Wildlife Corridors not formally identified and therefore increasing the land use conflicts between people and wildlife
Wildlife corridors to Hwange Nxai PanMaghadghadi Okavango Caprivi and key wildlife habitats eg Seloko formally identified and secured and land use conflicts reduced to 50 of current level

The Land Use Conflicts Identification Strategy LUCIS introduced to the Chobe District Land Board Land Use Planning authorities and stakeholders and has been accepted The LUCIS will help identify the land use conflicts and help in the formal identification of the corridors this will assist in developing strategies for securing the corridors

description.narrative: Collaborative Governance in PA and Buffer Zones Increasing Economic Growth and Removing Threats

Amount and of tourism fees reaching community
Employment
Uptake of wildlife management and land use zoning by communities

comment.narrative:
CECT P4m P150000 to each village
KALEPA P15m nil to each village
8 lions 10 elephant year

8 Villages receiving at least P400000 annually with 80 benefiting HH and providing at least 250 jobs
Communities employing game guards and providing MOMS and HWC reports
HWC reduced to 4 lions 5 elephants
LU zoning protection and business plans implemented and monitored
Livelihoods improve 15 especially for marginal people and women surveys
Governance tracking shows 65 performance and at least 30 women representation

Hunting ban has negatively affected the revenues that were accruing to the communities and there is no income from wildlife management in the CBNRM areas at the moment The project has started to work with the CBOs to overcome the above problem by promoting activitiesprojects that create employment and hire more people in a regular bases that are not seasonal
The project has started working with the womens group in Pandamatenga village to develop their capacities in crafts making The project has also developed the capacity of the Fishermens Association by providing materials equipment machinery and trainings on governance and leadership marketing quality assurance

description.narrative: Core protected areas strengthened financial sustainability and management effectiveness to address existing and emerging threats to biodiversity
Aquatic environment

comment.narrative: Baseline survey and threat assessment conducted by Y3

The project team has started discussions with the CARACAL a research NGO based in the project area to get to understand issues surrounding the aquatic environment and their findings indicate that the aquatic environment is faced with some threats The discussions will extend to the fishermen and other stakeholders to build a case for the threat assessment survey planned for Y3

description.narrative: Housing and equipment

comment.narrative:
Housing condition poor
5 vehicles

At least 50 staff houses rehabilitated with water electricity
10 vehicles

Through partnership with Chobe National Park management team 8 staff houses inside Chobe National Park and one 1 gate house at Mababe Gate have been identified for refurbishment The tendering process led by the Department of Wildlife and National Parks is expected to commence in around August 2015 and the awarding of the tender may be in the last quarter of 2015 and the actual work may commence in the first quarter of 2016 This is subject to the availability of a competitive bidder who meets the criteria and win the bid

description.narrative: Human resource capacity relative to KPAs

comment.narrative:
In Y1 review staff numbers and capacity relative to KPAs including job descriptions and performance criteria and initiate a staff development plan
At least 3 staff trained with degrees 15 with certificates and diplomas and 170 through professional short course training

Human resource evaluation and capacity needs assessment survey conducted in order to use the information to develop a Capacity Development Plan for the park staff The information provided by 17 staff members who responded to the questionnaire indicated that
staff members are not happy with their work conditions
their living conditions inside the park were not conducive to carry out their day to day activities
they lacked the right skills for park operation and management
As a support of the Capacity Development Plan a two day workshop for the park staff was planned in July 2015 to collect more information

description.narrative: Management information system

comment.narrative: Much unused data
Visualized data presented to stakeholders to support evidencebased decision making eg fires LE habitats wildlife CBNRM tourism etc

Discussions with the key stakeholders Research Unit of DWNP and other wildlife research bodies are in progress The purpose of the discussions is to brainstorm on the possible systems and how the data that are collected by different researchers could be presented and made available for the decisionmakers and the public The actual implementation is planned for year 2 quarter 1

description.narrative: Reduced area burned annually

comment.narrative: Average burnt area of 7 714 1 574 km2

Burned area reduced to 4000km2
Effective Community Based Fire Management Committees in place by year 1
Integrated Fire Management Strategy in place

Guidelines for Community Based Fire Management Committee developed discussed with the CBFMCs and awaiting approval by the larger stakeholders fire management workshop planned for quarter 3 2015 Workshop for introduction to Advanced Fire Information System AFIS for fire management conducted
Community Based Fire Management Committees in place in every villages in the project area District Fire Management Working Group Chobe Ngamiland established
Purchasing of firefighting equipment for the CBFMC process commenced

description.narrative: Tourism crowding and satisfaction

comment.narrative: No data
80 of tourists satisfied with game viewing along Chobe River frontage

Data collection tools to be developed in Quarter 3 with thee relevant authorities after the initial results of the Chobe River Frontage Decongestion Strategy which is being implemented by MWET The results of the survey will inform the relevant authorities on measures to be put in place to ensure that tourists are satisfied with game viewing along the Chobe River frontage

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Ngamiland SLM
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Provide technical support for sustainable land management practices from improved livelihoods

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

Component 1
1. Hectares of rangeland under improved management
2. Area of rangeland with improved grass and herbaceous species cover
3. Area of riparian woodland preserved or rehabilitated
4. Incidences of late dry season woodland fires
5. Extent of uncontrolled wildland fires
6. Area affected by bush encroachment
7. Number of farmers practicing Conservation Agriculture
8. Number of farmers practicing improved and effective herd management
9. Stocking rates inline with prevailing conditions of the rangeland
10. Number of farmers with improved livelihoods
11. Economic returns per land unit
12. Capacity of key land management institutions for SLM
Component 2
1. Multi-stakeholder forum for mainstreaming SLM issues in national and regional policies, plans and strategies
2. Revenue from Non beef livestock products
3. Offtake rate for cattle

comment.narrative:
Component 1
1. In terms of mainstreaming SLM in rangeland areas of Ngamiland District productive landscapes for improved livelihoods, there is no baseline i.e. (zero)
2. 64 000 ha denuded in commercial ranches
3. 10 000 ha of riparian woodland lost around lake Ngami
4. Fires burn annually at Tsodilo enclave
5. 10 000 ha affected by uncontrolled fires
6. 100 000 ha affected by over grazing and bush encroachment
7. 100 farmers practicing Conservation Agriculture (supported by Department of Crop Production and Southern African Regional Environment Program)
8. Zero baseline for farmers practicing improved and effective herd management
9. zero baseline line for stocking rates
10. Zero baseline for farmers with improved livelihoods
11. Zero baseline for economic returns per land unit
12. Key land management institutional capacity is 28%
Component 2
1. Existing multi-sectoral institution is limited to multiple government sectors only
2. Zero baseline for revenue from non beef livestock products
3. Cattle offtake rate from Ngamiland abattoirs is 100 cattle per day

Output : Project Management Supported
Target :1 PSC meeting convened per quarter
Output: Increased awareness on the project in Ngamiland
Target :4 publicity activities held
Output : Local level land use plans developed for Haina Veldt Ranches, Lake Ngami Toteng/ Maun Ranches
Target : 2 Land-use plans developed
Output : Improved range management and mixed livelihoods systems are piloted in line with the land use plans
Target: 60% of range management strategy developed and implemented .
Output : Fire management strategy piloted
Target: 3 training workshops
Output;1.5 Development of system for monitoring of range condition and productivity
Target: MOMS Consultant engaged by 31st March 2016.
Output: A regional multi-stakeholder forum for facilitating dialogue on SLM and mainstreaming SLM is created
Target: First meeting of the Ngamiland SLM forum convened by October 2016
Output: : Improved access of farmers to markets for livestock products
Target :Number of policy recommendations escalated to local and central government
Output :Processing plant in Ngamiland increases quantity variety of locally processed beef products, allowing higher sales of livestock products and off-take(supported through BMC co-financing)
Target : Abbatoir slaughters 120
Output : Product placement secured in local and regional markets (supported through BMC co-financing)
Target: Reports on at least 3 viable markets for Ngamiland beef produced by Dec 2015

Component 1.1; Local level land use plans Target: Grazing plans for Control farms, local level land use plan for Lake Ngami and Tsodilo
Component 1.2 Target: 10 tonnes of charcoal produced
Component 1.3 Target: 30,000Ha cleared of bush encroachment
Component 1.4 Target: 360 people trained in fire management Component 1.5 Target: 60 CA farmers trained in MOMS
Component 2.1 Target: 5 Multi Stakeholder dialogues held in 2017
Component 2.2 Target: 1 feasibility study on Community run abattoir in 2017
Component 2.3 Target: 2 community cluster groups(enterprises) trained in leather works in 2017.
Component 2.4 Target: 2 benchmarking trips in SADC and abroad to facilitate acquisition of beef market in 2017.

Component 1.1 Template for management plans for cattle ranches prepared and adopted by the control farms. Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) workshops done for Lake Ngami and Tsodilo. The PRAs are in preparation of local level land use plans.
Component 1.2. Process plans for charcoal production were done by the PMU. Training for Lake Ngami Trust in Charcoal production was undertaken in early August. Charcoal production has commenced at Lake Ngami
Component 1.3 Bush control has commenced in Lake Ngami. The encroaching Acacia species are being used to make charcoal.
Component 1.4. DFRR reported that there are success stories that relate to fire management. This is mainly due to the reduction in the area burnt and statistics were provided to confirm this reduction ranging from 2014-2016.The reduction is due in part to the fact that over 500 community members in 11 settlements around Tsodilo Hills have been trained in fire management and been given equipment to control bush fires. It was further reported that with the current fire season, DFRR have mobilized community teams to help with less hassle. These teams have been working on early burning and strengthening of fire breaks. DFRR was confident that fires will be suppressed within a short period of time.
component 1.5 An initial MOMS report showing yields and subsequent monitoring with a sample size of 20 farmers who benefited from the first season of CA in the district has shown that a lot of harvest was lost due to pests. The pests range from wild animals, domestic animals and pathogens. DCP further reported that MOMS training had been conducted and preparation for the next ploughing season was underway. Farmers were encouraged to record their MOMS books on a daily basis.
Component 2.1 DEA reported that two community dialogues in the villages of Shorobe and Kareng and one regional dialogue in Maun. The audience comprised multi-stakeholders from all sectors such as farmers, community leaders, business commun

description.narrative: To mainstream SLM in rangeland areas of Ngamiland District productive landscapes for improved livelihoods
Hectares of rangeland that are under improved management

comment.narrative: Zero

1 million hectares by project end
In addition it is expected that project lessons can be replicated to an additional 45 million hectares postproject

The project office has been erected furnished and officially opened About 90 of primary and secondary stakeholders identified in the PRODOC have been mobilized and consulted regarding their roles in the project A project board andor Project Steering Committee comprised of representatives of relevant local government agencies civil society organisations and print media has been established to provide policy and governance oversight to the Project Management Unit Moreover a Technical Reference Group TRG to assist in the review of consultancy Terms of Reference and other technical outputs has also been established Preparation of an Integrated range assessment studies to establish initial range and socioeconomic condition prior to management intervention are about to be undertaken following completion of draft terms of reference

description.narrative: Effective governance framework and markets provide incentives for livestock offtake and compliance with SLM
Multistakeholder forum for mainstreaming SLM issues in national and regional policies plans and strategies

comment.narrative: Existing multisectoral institution is limited to multiple government sectors
Active participation from government NGOs water and land user groups community trusts community leaders private sector by project end

Not yet established However virtually all project stakeholders have been consulted over the two first quarters of 2015 It is these same stakeholders that will comprise the forum The forum will be established and a schedule of themes for discussion developed and at least one forum meeting facilitated

description.narrative: Offtake rate for cattle

comment.narrative: Tbd during range assessments under the economic section
Tbd after range assessments
The Botswana Meat Commission owned Maun Abattoir is shutting down for renovations that are designed to increase offtake from about 80 cattle per day to 120 cattle per day

description.narrative: Revenue from nonbeef livestock products

comment.narrative: Zero
Tbd during feasibility studies for setting up a processing and marketing plant

No progress as yet However individuals and communities like those of Habu village with interest and experience in leather processing skull painting etc have been identified and will in the near future be assisted to participate in a ground breaking workshop as a precursor to feasibility studies

description.narrative: Effective range management improves range condition and flow of ecosystem services to support livelihoods of local communities
Area affected by bush encroachment

comment.narrative: 100000 ha affected by overgrazing and bush encroachment
Decrease by 25 by the end of the project
No progress as yet pending completion of integrated range assessment of all pilot areas The assessment studies and the emergent land use maps will guide scope and target for management interventions

description.narrative: Area of rangeland with improved grass and herbaceous species cover

comment.narrative: 64000 ha denuded in ranches
Approx 40 25600 ha in 4 ranches rehabilitated by project end

Range management interventions in ranches have not as yet been implemented Emerging from consultations with commercial farmers many are not happy with the selection of demonstration ranches A more transparent sampling technique for selection of demonstration ranches will have to be devised and agreed to by the farmersAlso held discussions with Ecoexist an organisation working in Ngamiland to reduce humanelephant conflict Their interventions could prove highly useful to commercial farmers in the project who have comlained bitterly about the negative impact elephants are having on their ranches ie cutting of fences

description.narrative: Area of riparian woodland preserved

comment.narrative: 10000 ha of riparian woodland lost around Lake Ngami
200 meter buffer zone reclaimed by project end

Received a special request for assistance from the Lake Ngami Conservation Trust to help with management of the Lake Solicited and obtained expressions of interest to provide manual labour for reclamation of Lake Ngami riparian zone from the University of Botswanas Environmental Club Commencement of reclamation activities shall await the projects procurement of equipment The completion of our integrated range assessment study of Lake Ngami and environs will also provide further guidance on how to best manage the riparian zone

description.narrative: Capacity of key land management institutions for SLM

comment.narrative: Summary baseline capacity score 28
Raise to 50 and improving by the end of the project

Most if not all relevant land management institutions are now members of the projects Technical Reference Group a development which has set the stage for a capacity self assessment to be undertaken and a capacity building training plan developed therefrom

description.narrative: Economic returns per land unit

comment.narrative: Tbd during range assessments which will include establishment of economic returns from different land uses ranches and communal rangelands
Increase returns by a quarter of the baseline every year after the 2nd year
Progress pending completion and implementation of management objectives as recommended by the integrated range assessment studies

description.narrative: Extent of uncontrolled fires

comment.narrative: 10000 ha affected by uncontrolled fire
Fireaffected area reduced by 50 most of the years and by 100 in two out of the five years of the project
No progress as yet This activity awaits a workshop to develop the draft Tsodilo Hills Fire Management Strategy which will be held in October 2015

description.narrative: Incidence of late dry season fires

comment.narrative: Fires burn annually at Tsodilo
Frequency reduced to every three years

Participated in two workshops organised by BIOCHOBE and the Department of Forestry and Range Resources investigating the efficacy of an Advanced Fire Information Management System AFIS The system is designed to facilitate remote detection of fires as a means to expedite ground level assets necessary to put out the fire It is hoped that atleast 40 of the Ngamiland districts land surface would be put under surveillance as part of the projects fire management strategy in the Tsodilo Hills area

description.narrative: No of farmers practicing conservation agriculture

comment.narrative: Zero
30 every other year trained and given extension support

Work with farmers has not yet commenced Instead discussions with Pabalelo Trust one of few non governmental organisations within Ngamiland district specializing in conservation agriculture have been held Discussions with more potential civil society partners on ways and means to promote CA among other things within the district are soon to be held

description.narrative: Stocking rates in line with the prevailing condition of the rangeland

comment.narrative: Tbd during the range assessment studies of this project
Tbd during the project and implemented in 4 ranches by project end

Following consultations with commercial farmers it has been established that stocking rates are generally difficult to enforce as a result of the extended nature of ranch ownership ie ranches are coowned by multiple members of one family who each contribute any number of cattle to the holding Moreover because of the unreliability of the Botswana Meat Commission in buying cattle for slaughter from farmers livestock from communal rangelands is often deliberately led into commercial ranching zone when word of imminent sale of livestock from the latter has been intercepted Government has since erected a protective fence between Haina Veld commercial ranches and communal areas but it is currently breached in many places due to both elephant and human vandals These issues shall be duly considered and used in the generation of management objectives and land use plans specific to the Haina Veld area

Output : Local level land use plans developed for each pilot(Mmatshumo, Mosu, Mokubilo and Mmea villages)
Target : Four Land Use and Management Plans available
Output :Improved range management and mixed livelihood systems are piloted in line with the land use plans

Target : Fire-affected area reduced by 50% in year two and three (i.e. at worst only 8,196 ha burnt)

Target 1.1: Four Land Use and Management Plans available
Target 1.2: Increased farm generated income of farmeer
Target 1.3: Fire-affected area reduced by 50% in year two and three (i.e. at worst only 8,196 ha burnt)
Target 2.1: Regional multi stakeholder forum
Target 2.2: A functional decision making support tool
Target 2.3: Annual MOMS reports published.

1.1 Four Land Use and Management Plans Completed. The pattern of the current built up area exhibits characteristics of traditional settlement which grew organically. Mmea and Makgaba are classified as a Tertiary III centre as per the National Settlement Policy. Of all the four plans for the four villages, Mosu village is mainly surrounded by escapements creating gullies and erosions from massive run offs during raining season. This poses a challenge in preparing appropriate expansion areas for the village especially that which will be agreeable to the community. The most plausible course seems to be to relocate new developments to a higher ground. This will greatly reduce conflicts in future. Some efforts were made by the Roads Department and Forest Conservation Botswana by creating gabions to address expansion of gullies but these were not so effective and was evident that a different approach needed to be done. Through the SLM project, BirdLife Botswana applied for funding from National Environment Fund to among others have a specific output geared towards doing an assessment on how best this kind of degradation could be addressed. The funding has been availed and the process will be done first quarter of 2018.
1.2. CA training done on the 16th and 17th August at Mosu for arable farmers, Effective Herd management done on the 23rd and 25th August at Mosu for small tock farmers. Training on CA done at Mosu ( and Mmatshumo (16th April 2017) respectively where famers were adviced to form groups to further advance thier collective participantion. For 2017 only 76 famers were trained on CA. The training session also included lessons from 2016 where key challenges were discussed with an intension to address them in the next coming season.
1.3.Fire-affected area reduced by 50% in year two and three (i.e. at worst only 8,196 ha burnt): By the 12th June 2017, the Draft Final Land Use Plan have been available and presented to the TRG, Sub DLUPU, main DLUPU (10th August

comment.narrative: HIV/AIDS and gender not mainstreamed into Transport, Infrastructure, Science and Technology National Policies
mainstreaming strategy developed by Nov 2016

The Reference Group was launched on the 6th March 2016. The new team reviewed the TORs for the proposed consultant and the TORs for the Reference Group. The consultant was to be procured to work on the project so that it will be done by end of September 2016. Since then no other meeting for the reference group. The consultant has not started. UNDP was informed that there are challenges with the procurement of the consultant and till September end the consultant was not procured. Consultative meeting 30th March 2016 There was a consultative meeting with the Permanent Secretaries on the 30th March for the ministries for the buy in of the project. UNDP provided some presentation to Permanent Secretaries and Ministerial AIDS Coordinators of the 3 sector ministries on EIA and its inception. The meeting was held at NACA and chaired by Permanent Secretary/ NACA Coordinator Ms. Grace Muzila
The activity was not carried over to 2017
The activity was not carried over to 2017

comment.narrative: Certain acts of key populations especially men who have sex with men and sex workers are criminalized and service providers attitudes prevent access to health services. Stigma and discrimination against people with diverse sexual orientation and gender identify and sex workers still persist. Botswana has no integrated strategy on alcohol and substance abuse that address gender based violence, HIV/AIDS and NCDs. Botswana has not fully utilized TRIPS flexibilities.

Component 1 i. Validated alcohol policy desk review assessment report. ii. Road map for implementing key recommendations. iii. Integrated strategic plan and iv. revised/updated alcohol policy Component 2 i. TWG for TRIPS flexibilities established ii. Electronic repositories for patented medicines iii. Regional Collaboration Plan Component 3 80% of the target service providers aware of the needs of the key population and vulnerable groups. Component 4 Validated National legal Environment Assessment Report for HIV and the Law. Component 5 Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Right (SOGIR) assessment report completed.

Component 1 i. Alcohol policy Desk review done. Report finalized and printed. ii. Road map to be finalized. iii. TORs and concept note for strategic plan iv. TORs for alcohol policy review done and awaiting government feedback for cost sharing. Component 2 i. TWG for TRIPS flexibilities established ii. TORs and concept note done and shared with MOHw iii. Regional collaboration plan pending Component 3 - 2 human rights dialogues done. 60 service providers trained on human rights for key populations and vulnerable groups. Component 4 - LEA report complete, awaiting design and printing. Component 5 - TOR done. NSC constituted. consultation has generated inception report.

comment.narrative:
Economic Diversification Drive
Local Economic Development Policy Framework

Finalize PRODOC for approval.
LED business plans for Sowa, Francistown, Kgalagadi and Chobe developed
Facilitate local economic analysis in Central, North West; Ghanzi; Southern; South East and Lobatse districts
Development of the South-South Cooperation Strategy for Botswana
Support the preparation of HLPF, VNRs and 2017 Botswana SDGs progress report

Finalize PRODOC for approval The project has facilitated the drafting of the Economic Diversification and Inclusive Growth Project Document now under consideration by the Government of Botswana Representative (Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry). To date, two (2) stakeholders workshops with participation of Implementing Partners were facilitated with UNDP providing technical support in the drafting of the document. The document defines a four (4) year project aimed at supporting the Government of Botswana to address the challenges of diversifying sources of economic growth, eradicate poverty and reduce inequalities and exclusion. Emphasis is also placed on the support to both the public and private sector to adopt the Supplier Development Programme (SDP) as a strategic tool to insert indigenous firms in the supply chains and to build their competitiveness through skills development.
LED business plans for Sowa, Francistown, Kgalagadi and Chobe developed Following the development and approval of their LED strategies that have identified different sectors and priority areas in which they have comparative advantages, the districts of Sowa Town, Francistown, Chobe and Kgalagadi has undergone various capacity development interventions. These included training, mentoring and coaching of relevant stakeholders in the districts to identify and develop product value chain maps and business concepts for their LED projects. These product value chains and business concepts are ready to be developed into bankable business plans for investment and implementation.
The focus of the ongoing support is to assist the four districts to transform the combination of product value chain maps and business concepts into bankable business plans. The bankable business plans will form the basis for attracting different sources and types of resources to finance implementation of the LED projects - value chain finance [VCF]. The VCF process focuses on identifying the elements that r
